page.title: 01Upper Tima, Ettrick Valley
page.content: The Tima, a major tributary of the river Ettirick runs from South to North, fed by the Nether Dalgliesh and Glenkerry burns, through a wide flat gravelled valley. The hills on either side rise to a height of 500mts and are almost entirely covered with plantations of Sitka Spruce and Larch, with the exception of the highest tops which are ungrazed and unplanted. By the road side some deciduous trees have been planted for their amenity value. The river bed is covered in summer with a variety of wild flowers, and is the habitat of nesting migrant birds such as Curlew, Oyster Catcher, Lapwing, Plover, and Snipe. All year round there are heron and goosanders and other native wildlife include Fox, Mink, Stoat, Weasel, Frogs, Toads and frequent small herds of deer.
